payload.text:
Here is the updated prompt with specific instructions to make the website **vibrant, colorful, and energetic**, avoiding any black or dark themes.

***

**Copy and paste the following prompt into Google AI Studio:**

***

**Role & Objective:**
Act as an expert Full-Stack Developer and Creative UI/UX Designer. Your task is to design and develop a professional **Multi-Page Website** (consisting of 5 distinct pages) for **Abridge Media Services**. The site should be colorful, energetic, and visually engaging, moving away from standard corporate looks.

**Brand Identity & Vibe:**
*   **Name:** Abridge Media Services.
*   **Philosophy:** "Design - Develop." Bridging the gap between imagination and execution.
*   **Tone:** Professional yet highly creative, energetic, and approachable.
*   **Visual Style & Color Palette:**
    *   **Theme:** **Vibrant & Colorful.** Absolutely **NO** black backgrounds or dark themes.
    *   **Base:** Use clean white or very light gray backgrounds for content areas to ensure readability.
    *   **Accents:** Use **vivid gradients** (e.g., blends of Electric Blue, Hot Pink, Bright Orange, and Violet) for the Hero section, CTA buttons, and decorative elements.
    *   **Cards:** Use soft pastel backgrounds (light blue, light pink, light yellow) for service cards to distinguish them from the white background.
    *   **Typography:** Use bold, modern sans-serif fonts. Headings should be colorful or have gradient text effects.

**Architecture & Page Requirements:**

**Global Elements (Apply to All Pages):**
*   **Header:** White or light-colored sticky top navigation containing: Logo (Colorful text), Links (Home, About, Services, Packages, Blog, Store), and a "Contact Us" CTA button (Gradient background).
*   **Footer:** White background with colorful icons/social links. Contact details and copyright info. **Crucial:** Do not include a physical address or Google Map.

---

**Page 1: Home (index.html)**
*   **Hero Section:** Full-screen **colorful gradient background** (e.g., Blue to Purple). Headline in White: "We Build the Visual Foundation of Your Business."
*   **Intro/Philosophy:** White background section with colorful icons describing the "Design - Develop" philosophy.
*   **Services Snapshot:** A grid of 4 cards. Each card should have a different vibrant pastel background color (Light Blue, Light Orange, Light Green, Light Purple) representing the 4 pillars.
*   **CTA Section:** A bright, solid color section (like Yellow or Coral) with bold text: "Ready to energize your vision?"

**Page 2: About Us (about.html)**
*   **Header:** "Who We Are."
*   **Content:** Use a split layout. On one side, text; on the other, a colorful abstract illustration or shape.
*   **Why Choose Us:** Use a checklist with colorful bullet points or checkmarks.

**Page 3: Services (services.html)**
*   **Layout:** Organize the 4 Pillars into distinct blocks.
*   **Styling:** Alternate background colors for each pillar section (e.g., White background for Pillar 1, Light Gray for Pillar 2, Light Blue for Pillar 3) to keep the page visually interesting and colorful.
*   **Content details:**
    *   *Brand Foundation:* Logo design, Brand identity/style guides, Business cards, Stationery, Icon design.
    *   *Digital Experience:* Website & UI/UX design, Web banners, Thumbnails, Online graphic creation.
    *   *Marketing & Print:* Brochures/flyers, Ad creatives, Social media assets, Presentations, Posters, Menus, Signage.
    *   *The Plus:* Packaging & merchandise, Cap/T-shirt designing, Book covers, Labels.

**Page 4: Packages & Pricing (packages.html)**
*   **Note on Currency:** Display all prices as **INR (₹) Primary** with **USD ($)** in parentheses.
*   **Section 1: Logo Design Packages:** Use cards with a "Pop" border color.
    *   *Starter:* ₹3000 ($50).
    *   *Best Buy:* ₹5000 ($75). Make this card stand out with a colorful gradient background.
*   **Section 2: Website Packages:** Display in colorful bordered boxes.
    *   *Template Design:* ₹3,000 ($35).
    *   *Standard Website:* ₹16,000 - ₹22,000 ($182 - $250).
    *   *E-Commerce:* ₹45,000 ($550).
*   **Section 3: A La Carte Graphic Design List:** A clean table or list with colorful row highlights.
    *   (Include all list items: Social Media Poster ₹400, Business Cards ₹400, Letter Head ₹400, Brochure A4 ₹1000, Company Profile ₹750, Magazine ₹750, Coupons ₹500, Cover page ₹400, Website Banner ₹500, Product Packaging ₹2000-5000, Catalogue ₹750, Menu card ₹3000).
*   **Section 4: Terms & Conditions:** Simple, clean text box.

**Page 5: Contact (contact.html)**
*   **Layout:** Split screen.
*   **Left Side (Info):** **Vibrant Gradient Background** with White text. Details: Mobile +91 9881103444, WhatsApp +91 9881103444, Email 004neil@gmail.com.
*   **Right Side (Form):** White background with colorful input field borders (focus states).
*   **External Links:** Colorful buttons linking to the Store (`https://payhip.com/Creativelyink`) and Blog (`https://creativelyink.blogspot.com/`).

**Technical Requirements:**
*   **File Structure:** Generate code for a standard multi-page website (index, about, services, packages, contact).
*   **Responsiveness:** Fully responsive on mobile and tablet.
*   **Color Theory:** Ensure high contrast between text and background. If using a colorful background, use white text. If using a white background, use dark or colorful text.
*   **Design:** Use CSS variables for easy color management (e.g., `--primary-gradient`, `--accent-pink`, `--accent-blue`).

**Defining the UI Look**

I'm solidifying the aesthetic direction for Abridge Media Services. The goal is vibrancy and energy, avoiding any black or dark themes. I'm leaning toward clean, light backgrounds, likely white or light gray, to keep the content front and center.


**Refining the Color Palette**

I'm now focusing on the visual elements, specifically colors, fonts, and the layout. I've chosen vivid gradients and soft pastels for a clean, modern look. I plan to use a sticky header and footer. I've also outlined the page structure, and the tech stack to build it. I'm leveraging React 18+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The folder structure and components are also laid out.

React application entry point.
Shared types for the application.
Global constants including color palettes and design data.
Sticky header component with navigation and colorful branding.
Clean, light footer component with social icons and contact links.

payload.text: can you give me different layout and colors

**Revising Site Aesthetics**

I'm now contemplating a layout and color scheme overhaul for the Abridge Media Services website. The previous design employed a "vibrant, colorful, and energetic" aesthetic with white backgrounds and vivid gradients. Now, I'm focusing on exploring alternative visual directions.


**Exploring New Aesthetic Directions**

I'm now diving into alternative visual concepts, prioritizing a fresh creative direction while maintaining the client's "energetic and professional" core. I'm focusing on "Tropical Punch" or "Neon Oasis" color palettes instead of standard gradients, considering deep teal, electric lime, and soft peach. I'm also looking into editorial typography, potentially serif headings paired with clean sans-serif bodies, while considering the weights and spacing of 'Plus Jakarta Sans'. I'm envisioning asymmetrical grids, "split hero" sections with overlapping elements for the home page, and a "Bento Box" layout or horizontal scroll format for the service sections.


**Refining Visual Concepts**

I'm now iterating on the visual approach. I've decided to shift from a simple split to a layered look with floating images. The color palette will consist of Indigo-600, Emerald-400, Rose-400, and Slate-50 for the surface. I'm aiming for a Retro-Modern aesthetic with thick, polished borders and glassmorphism for the header. I'll need to update `index.html`, `constants.tsx`, and relevant component files to reflect these changes, also changing the layouts of several key pages.

I will update the application with a fresh **"Electric Oasis"** theme. 

### Specification Updates:
1.  **Color Palette:** Transitioning from the previous blue/pink gradients to a sophisticated yet high-energy palette of **Teal, Coral, Deep Lavender, and Mint**. I'll use a `Slate-50` off-white for sections to add depth without being "dark."
2.  **Layout Changes:**
    *   **Header:** Shifted from a standard top-bar to a **floating glassmorphism "pill" navigation** that centers itself on scroll.
    *   **Home Hero:** Swapping the full-screen gradient for a **dynamic split-screen "Layered" layout** with floating geometric accents.
    *   **Services:** Moving from simple vertical blocks to a **"Bento Box" grid** for the pillars, giving it a modern tech-startup feel.
    *   **Packages:** Redesigning the pricing cards to use **"Elevated Brutalism"**—thick colorful borders and offset shadows for a high-impact, tactile look.
3.  **Visual Polish:** Adding subtle "blob" decorations in the background and using **Variable Weights** in typography to create better hierarchy.

entries.description: Update the color variables and global styles for the "Electric Oasis" theme.
Update the color values and icons for the new theme.
Redesign header as a floating glassmorphism pill navigation.
Overhaul the Home page with a split-layered hero and Bento-box style pillar grid.

payload.text:
**Identifying Missing Imports**

I'm currently focused on pinpointing the root cause of the "Cannot find name" errors within `pages/Home.tsx`. The issue appears to stem from a failure to import the necessary `Monitor` and `Share2` components from `lucide-react`. I will focus on the third line of the file, to find missing imports or typos.


**Adding Missing Imports**

I've determined the issue in `pages/Home.tsx`. I need to add `Monitor` and `Share2` to the existing `lucide-react` import. I'll insert them to the import statement as `<Monitor, Share2>`. I will be updating the file to correct the import on line 3 to: `import { ArrowUpRight, Zap, Target, MousePointer2, Monitor, Share2 } from 'lucide-react';`


**Verifying Component Imports**

I've confirmed `Monitor` and `Share2` were the sole missing imports in `pages/Home.tsx` and have corrected the import statement. Now, I'm verifying if other files across the codebase also have any potential import errors, though I don't expect any. I've scanned the other components and pages.


**Analyzing Component Usage**

I'm now examining how the `ITEMS` constant is being utilized within `pages/Home.tsx`. I need to understand its role in shaping the component's output. I'm focusing on the rendering logic within the `return` statement, specifically the `div` with the className "pt-20", and looking for where `ITEMS` is called, and how its fields are rendered to the DOM.


**Evaluating Text Content**

I am now focusing on the text content within `pages/Home.tsx`, specifically the introduction section. I'm scrutinizing the heading and paragraph copy to ensure clarity and impact. I need to make sure the message clearly conveys the value proposition of the business. I want to assess the call-to-action buttons as well, to gauge their effectiveness.


**Assessing Visual Hierarchy**

I'm now diving into the visual structure of the components on the page. I'm focusing on the grid layout within the section and how its elements are arranged, especially the card-like containers, and the use of the teal, white, and rose color palette. I am examining how visual elements, such as the `Target` icon's positioning and scaling effects, guide the user's eye and reinforce the message.


**Refining Section Structure**

I'm now zeroing in on the "Bento Pillar Grid" section. My goal is to understand how the components on this page are arranged and whether they properly align with the structure that has been planned. I'm taking a close look at the grid's visual flow and the elements' arrangement, paying particular attention to their grouping and how they work in conjunction with each other to communicate with the user.


**Examining Pillar Structure**

I'm now closely reviewing the "Built on 4 Pillars" section's structure in `pages/Home.tsx`, specifically the first pillar's implementation. I'm focused on the responsiveness of the grid and the visual balance achieved through the column and row spans. I'm assessing the content within the first pillar, including the icon's size and positioning, the heading's emphasis, and the text's alignment. I need to make sure the structure works as designed.


**Evaluating Pillar Elements**

I'm now analyzing the second and third pillars within the "Built on 4 Pillars" section of `pages/Home.tsx`. I'm comparing their content, structure, and visual presentation to the first pillar. I'm focusing on consistency in the use of icons, headings, descriptions, and the overall layout. I want to make sure the pillars are properly aligned with the rest of the section.


**Assessing Pillar Presentation**

I'm now examining the visual presentation and content of the fourth pillar. I'm focusing on the wide layout, contrasting it with the other pillars in the "Built on 4 Pillars" section. I need to understand the relationship between the text and the blur effect, also whether these design decisions properly reinforce the message, and whether the design choices create a logical and engaging user experience.


**Reviewing Call-to-Action**

I'm now zeroing in on the call-to-action section, specifically the "Explore Plus" button's placement and design, in the "Philosophy Section". I need to verify its impact and the effectiveness of the button text. The goal is to verify it prompts the user to move forward. I'll make sure this works correctly.


**Analyzing Item Rendering**

I'm now focused on understanding how the `OPHY_ITEMS` array renders content within `pages/Home.tsx`. I am looking at the mapping process and how each item's `icon`, `title`, and `description` are displayed. I need to ensure the visual elements and text are rendered correctly in each `div` element.

payload.text: this is good. the only thing please highlight the store button.

**Prioritizing the Store Button**

I'm focusing on highlighting the "Store" button in the navigation. Right now, it's just another link within `Header.tsx`, but I want to make it stand out. My next steps involve exploring different visual treatments to increase its prominence and give it special treatment.

entries.description: Highlight the "Store" button in the navigation bar to make it more prominent and visually distinct.

payload.text:
please change the logo using below mentioned link

LOGO :- https://photos.fife.usercontent.google.com/pw/AP1GczPBKV3xs0lYgd8bVtFu31wUIK9Twk7jHDz3dWDXx4QtmxpSlb9Tq5eB8g=w723-h290-s-no-gm?authuser=0

**Considering Logo Placement**

I'm currently focused on integrating the image-based logo. I've pinpointed `components/Header.tsx` as the target file. The user-provided URL, `https://photos.fife.usercontent.google.com/pw/AP1GczPBKV`, will be used to source the new logo image, replacing the existing text or icon representation. This step feels straightforward.


**Analyzing Image URL Issues**

I'm now evaluating the direct Google Photos link, as these can expire or require authentication. I'm focusing on embedding it as an `img` tag within `components/Header.tsx` and `components/Footer.tsx`. Initial inspection of the `Header.tsx` file confirms the target location; I will replace the existing visual components with the new logo. The same will be done with the branding in the footer file, given the user request to "change the logo".


**Implementing Image Logo**

I'm now implementing the image logo in both the header and footer. I'm focusing on the `components/Header.tsx` and `components/Footer.tsx` files. I plan to use the provided Google Photos URL directly, despite potential expiration issues. Styling adjustments are underway, specifically height, to ensure the wide logo displays correctly, with `h-8` or `h-10` being considered for the header. I have replaced the existing visual components in the `Header.tsx` file with the image tag, using a reasonable height like `h-8`.

entries.description: Replace the text-based logo with the provided image logo URL in the navigation bar.
Replace the text-based branding in the footer with the provided logo image.

please change the logo using below mentioned link

https://scontent-bom5-2.xx.fbcdn.net/v/t39.30808-6/626778663_122102633553247608_6348987989825248532_n.jpg?_nc_cat=100&ccb=1-7&_nc_sid=127cfc&_nc_ohc=nEkDCMHhGfMQ7kNvwFRnWeq&_nc_oc=AdlbetXYtWnY3XMqnyPFuLO6nCJ2LK1JfHIJEML9VkD8FuGwYuhH-1TSaIGyzq3fPxI&_nc_zt=23&_nc_ht=scontent-bom5-2.xx&_nc_gid=ffd4-Rt2poYsEMVgYtv74Q&oh=00_AfsbfeFxd0dLleA_Q3wbFWn8d1HYLbfUKs2Urz8-pQsqUw&oe=698E1B91

**Updating Logo Details**

I'm now focusing on implementing the new logo URL. The previous one was either invalid or the user's preference has changed, so I'm replacing the old URL in `components/Header.tsx` with the new Facebook CDN link they provided. This seems straightforward, and I'll keep the expert user posted as soon as the update is live.


**Reviewing Logo Location**

I'm now cross-referencing the logo URL's location. I've successfully updated the `LOGO_URL` in both `components/Header.tsx` and `components/Footer.tsx`, and I'm aware the Facebook CDN link could expire. I will keep the image fallback and updated URL in both files. Next, I plan to move forward with confirming my understanding with the expert user.


**Implementing Logo Updates**

I'm now in the process of replacing the existing logo URL in `Footer.tsx` with the new link from the expert user, and I'm noting the existing logo URLs in `Header.tsx` and `Footer.tsx`. The user mentioned the new URL, which looks like a signed Facebook CDN URL, so I'm conscious of potential expiry. I'm keeping the fallback in place as a precaution. Given the logo's JPEG format, I'm checking the image sizing relative to the current `h-10` in header and `h-12` in footer. I'll make sure the background appears correct relative to the existing style.


**Analyzing Header Logic**

I'm now investigating the header component's functionality. I see it uses React hooks like `useState` and `useEffect` for state management and side effects, and utilizes `useLocation` from `react-router-dom` to track the current route. The code handles scrolling events to change the header's appearance and defines navigation links with name and path or href. It also includes functions to check if the current path matches a link's path. I'll evaluate the menu's state in mobile.


**Evaluating Logo Source**

I'm now focusing on assessing the logo image source itself. Examining the provided URL, it seems to be a Facebook CDN link, potentially signed. I'm taking note of its structure and considering the implications for its longevity and possible expiration. I will consider any necessary fallback mechanisms, and make a plan to implement them.



**Refining Navigation Logic**

I'm now implementing logic to manage fallback text when the image fails to load. I added a span with the text "ABRIDGE" that displays dynamically if the logo image fails. Also, I'm refactoring the navigation links to handle desktop display, with conditional styling for active links and hover effects. I'm focusing on ensuring these updates are responsive.


**Implementing Navigation Styling**

I'm now integrating the updated navigation styling. I've focused on conditional styling for active links, hover effects, and the special "Store" link. I'm leveraging Tailwind classes for responsiveness and visual feedback. I'm also addressing the mobile menu button and ensuring it aligns with the updated design.


**Adjusting Mobile Menu**

I'm now evaluating the mobile menu's visual behavior and responsiveness. I'm focusing on ensuring it displays correctly across different screen sizes, specifically addressing the mobile menu button and its interaction. I'm also confirming that it aligns with the updated design.


**Refining Mobile Menu**

I'm now implementing updates to the mobile menu. I'm leveraging the isOpen state to control its visibility, and added a conditional rendering block in the code. I'm focusing on the styling, and how it appears in different screen sizes. I've integrated styling for active links, hover effects and special links like "Store", and making sure Get in Touch has the correct styling.


**Implementing Footer Update**

I'm now implementing the changes to the footer component. I've integrated the new logo URL in the footer. I've focused on ensuring the logo displays correctly, with the fallback implemented. I'm focusing on ensuring it is correctly sized and displays the image or fallback text smoothly.


**Adding Footer Content**

I'm now integrating the provided footer content. I've added the new text content and styled it to match the existing design, including the gradient for the heading and the text for the description. I'm focusing on ensuring it is correctly formatted. I will update the styling, with the goal of matching the style of the rest of the application.

entries.description: Updated logo URL to the new Facebook CDN link provided by the user.

payload.text:
add this text in Brand Foundation section

At Abridge Media Services, our Brand Foundation pillar is dedicated to building strong visual identities from the ground up. We define exactly who you are by providing professional Logo Design and comprehensive Brand Style Guides. Beyond the core logo, we ensure your business is ready for the real world with essential stationery design, including business cards, letterheads, and custom icons, laying the groundwork for a cohesive and professional brand image.

**Adding Brand Foundation Text**

I'm now focused on incorporating the user's specific text description into the "Brand Foundation" section of the "Services" page, ensuring it complements the existing colorful design. I've begun modifying the `pages/Services.tsx` file to achieve this, focusing on a clean integration.


**Refining Brand Integration**

I'm now integrating the provided "Brand Foundation" text directly into the `pages/Services.tsx` file, specifically within a new `description` field for the "Brand Foundation" section. I've analyzed the file structure and will update the `sections` array to include this field, ensuring the energetic aesthetic is maintained alongside a clean and professional layout.


**Adjusting Display Logic**

I'm now revising how the "Brand Foundation" description will be displayed on the "Services" page. Previously, I planned on integrating the new text as a description in the `sections` array and rendering it, but the UI renders items as list items, meaning I will add a `longDescription` property. I am updating the rendering logic in `pages/Services.tsx` to handle this new property.


**Integrating Long Description**

I am now focusing on integrating the provided detailed "Brand Foundation" text into the `pages/Services.tsx` file. I've opted to add a `longDescription` property to the `sections` array in that file. I will ensure this new description renders correctly before the existing list items. I'm avoiding updating `constants.tsx` because the detailed descriptions belong exclusively on the Services page, while the Home page uses a brief summary. I've now checked the component structure and will insert the paragraph there.

entries.description: Add the detailed description for the Brand Foundation section and update the card layout to accommodate the additional text.

); }; export default Services;

At Abridge Media Services, our Brand Foundation pillar is dedicated to building strong visual identities from the ground up. payload.text: I want to collect data from all the forms on my website through this formspree link. please connect the forms appropriately. https://formspree.io/f/mgolebog

**Analyzing Form Implementations**

I'm currently focused on connecting all website forms to the Formspree endpoint. My initial look is at `pages/Contact.tsx` for implementation details. I'll need to confirm that this is the only form, or find others. The endpoint is set to `https://formspree.io/f/mgolebog`.


**Refining Form Implementation Strategy**

I've determined the main form needing attention is in `pages/Contact.tsx` as well as others that may be implicit. My plan is to update the contact form to submit to Formspree, ensuring correct input names. I'll add a feedback mechanism for success/errors. Although there are some "Call to Action" buttons, I'll focus on the primary contact form to meet the requirements of the request.


**Evaluating Form Submission Scope**

I'm now considering the "Request Custom Bundle" button within `Services.tsx`. While a link to the contact page is simpler, the prompt specified "all forms". My current plan involves either linking it to the contact page or adding a minimal form. But simplicity is the key here. Ultimately, I'll prioritize linking it for now to the main contact form, and will address that form's implementation.


**Prioritizing Form Integration**

I'm now focusing on `Contact.tsx`. I'll implement a state to manage submission status (idle, loading, success, error) and use `fetch` for submission to Formspree, updating the UI accordingly. While standard HTML form submission is possible, I'll stick to a modern AJAX approach, given the project goals. I'll stick to updating `Contact.tsx` for now and delay addressing other possible implicit forms. I'll stick to `Contact.tsx` for now.


**Expanding Form Submission Scope**

I'm now expanding the scope to consider other potential forms besides the main contact form. I've located several "call to action" button click locations within the site: "Request Custom Bundle", "Select Starter", "Start Pro Identity", and "Start Your Project". My current priority remains ensuring that `Contact.tsx` functions flawlessly with Formspree, and then determining how to address the "Request Custom Bundle" button. I'm leaning toward simplifying and linking it to the main contact form at this stage. I am now rethinking this and will add a light capture form.


**Identifying Form Targets**

I'm now expanding my search for forms beyond `Contact.tsx`. I've discovered call-to-action buttons in `Home.tsx`, `Work.tsx`, and `Packages.tsx`, which will require attention. The original scope includes "all the forms", so I'll check the current code for `<form>` tags. I'm prioritizing `Contact.tsx` for now and plan to also add a small form to `Services.tsx`. I'm starting by ensuring proper submission handling within `Contact.tsx`.


**Implementing Form Submission Logic**

I'm now integrating submission logic into `Contact.tsx`, including state management for submission status, leveraging `fetch` for AJAX calls to Formspree. I'm handling success and error cases, including resetting the form on success and displaying error messages to the user. I'll make sure to handle errors gracefully, providing feedback. I'm focusing on ensuring robust error handling in all forms.


**Refactoring Form Submission Targets**

I'm now prioritizing the main `Contact.tsx` form, noting the existing `onSubmit` preventing submission. I'll modify it to leverage a real submission handler. I'll also add `name` attributes to all input fields for data collection. I've re-evaluated other implicit forms and I plan to convert the "Request Custom Bundle" button to a link to `Contact.tsx`. I'll address these changes next.

entries.description: Connect the contact form to Formspree, add input name attributes, and implement submission handling with success/error states.
